content:
Ass indifferent to enemy‘s approach: he could be no more
miserable than now.
To have good servants a lord must be good.

(Frogs, crickets.) Wienert FFC LVI 61, *66 (ET 232, 304),
123 (ST 321, 322); Halm Aesop Nos. 172, 248.
No great knights now because no great kings.
Beard on she-goats do not make a male.
Man soon learns to stand the smells of the tannery.

Wienert FFC LVI 81 (ET 474), 111 (ST 226); Halm Aesop No.
368; India: Thompson-Balys.
child: Farmer prefers stable smells to flowers.

Latter make him ill.
Wesselski Mönchslatein 13 No. 8; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

content: Mountain in labor brings forth a mouse.

Wienert FFC LVI *44 (ET 24), *101 (ST 141); Jacobs Aesop
203 No. 14; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

child:
Fox finally converses with lion whom he had feared at
first.

Wienert FFC LVI 60 (ET 224), 111
(ST 224); Halm Aesop No. 39; Jacobs Aesop 208 No. 34.

Men at first frightened at camel take him into their
service.

Wienert FFC LVI 66 (ET 306), 111
(ST 224); Halm Aesop No. 180.

Newly rich cannot resist call for distribution of food to
beggars.

content:
Mill horse when taken to war keeps going in a circle, as he
has learned in the mill.

Fisher and hunter exchange catches for variety: soon return
to original food.
child:
Dissatisfied workmen exchange work: still more
dissatisfied.
Beasts and fishes exchange places: fatal to both.

content: Longing for accustomed food and living.
child: At feast cat chooses rat meat; other animals cannot eat it.
Shepherd in king‘s palace sickens for country air.
Former slave sickens for accustomed food.

Peasant girl married to king longs for peasant ways of
eating.

Peasants fed white bread demand the rye bread to which they
are accustomed.

content:
Knight doesn’t want to go to heaven if there are no hunting
dogs there.

A
father asks about his son. When he hears that he lies, he gives the son up as
hopeless. Other sins may be outgrown. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 393; Spanish
Exempla: Keller.
child: Liar cannot be healed even when taking bath in the Ganges.

content: Habit of dishonesty (thievery) cannot be broken.
child:
Dishonest silversmith restless until silver ornament is
mixed with alloy.

content: Other ways in which appearances deceive.
child:
At a funeral of a child a satyr reveals that the real
father (officiating priest) sings while the cuckold weeps.

At a hanging the witnesses are bigger thieves than the
culprit.
Peasant wishes to exchange places with monks.

Thinks they lead a very easy life. One night‘s experience
in the monastery makes him change his mind. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Handsome exterior does not indicate beautiful soul.

Angel holds nose when handsome sinner passes. Spanish
Exempla: Keller.
An ugly face does not mean an ugly soul.

A noble and holy man who is very ugly is proved to be a
saintly soul. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Stories to show that one’s name does not alter his
condition.

content:
Wolf having eaten too much meat promises God to eat no
more meat. When he becomes well he eats as before. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 307.
child: False repentance of the sick, rich man.

After his death it was discovered that he had intended to
retrieve his money from church if he recovered. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

content:
Blind man crosses a narrow bridge which his guide is afraid
to attempt.
The bad custom in the world: the young die as well as the old.

Hence youth enters monastery. *Crane Vitry 184 No. 116;
Alphabet No. 212; *Mensa Philosophica No. 181.

Futile attempt to explain to a blind man meaning of
“white”.

Two blind men succeed in fooling each other about their
blindness.

Man unable to persuade wife to confess misdeed to priest
succeeds when he makes her drunk.
Hypocrite is acclaimed as saint after his death.
Tree cut down with axe for which it has furnished a handle.

Wienert FFC LXI *74 (ET 388), 117 (ST 274); Halm Aesop No.
123; Jewish: *Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys.

Hermit having rebuked youth falls himself when exposed to
the same sin.
child: Monk rebukes brethren who succumb to temptation.

When he is exposed to it he understands what temptation
is. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

content: Royalty unable to endure coarse entertainment.
child: Coarse food, etc., sends adulterous king back to his wife.

content: Animals try unsuccessfully to exchange food.

Nightingale cannot lodge with birds whose nest is made of
manure.
Ox likes loving strokes of man; flea fears them.

Wienert FFC LVI 60 (ET 223), 121 (ST 307); Halm Aesop No.
426.

child:
Monk leaves monastery when he sees a devil there tempting
brethren.

Returns when in the world he
sees scores of devils tempting the people. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

content: Enmity between fisherman and dweller on the river.

Fishing stirs up the
water and makes it unfit for drinking. (Cf. †U31.) Wienert FFC LVI 84 (ET 512),
121 (ST 303); Halm Aesop No. 25.

Tiger son of human mother scratches her and licks her
blood.
child: Tiger father of human child licks its blood.

content: Good weather for one is foul for another.
Cf. Heywood’s Play of the Weather.

What is one man‘s food is another man’s
poison--miscellaneous.

child: Crab walks backward: learned from his parents.

*Crane Vitry 152 No. 44; Wienert FFC LVI *63 (ET 258),
*103 (ST 159); Halm Aesop No. 187.
Hind, like his mother, flees before the hounds.

Useless for her to urge him to stand up against them.
Wienert FFC LVI *63 (ET 256), 103 (ST 158, 501); Halm Aesop No. 130.
Farmer‘s son and noble’s reared in country.

The former takes to toil on farm, the latter to riding and
hunting. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Alleged son of king proved to be bastard when he displays
habits of his true father.
Father, like son, acts foolishly at king‘s court.
Butcher’s son becomes cruel and atrocious ruler.

content: Dungbeetle prefers his dunghill to all other smells.

Wienert FFC LVI 60 (ET 217), 119 (ST 292); Halm Aesop No.
185; Herbert III 35ff.; India: Thompson-Balys.
child:
Beetles treated with as much honor as oxen will not learn
to act as oxen.

content:
Scorpion, in spite of himself, stings the turtle carrying
him across the stream.
Courage conquers all and impossible is made possible.
Hares fearing death outrun pursuing dogs.
child:
Surrounded by hunters and hounds, the hare considers to whom each of his
members will be allotted. Succeeds in escaping. Lithuanian: Balys Index No.
160*; Prussian: Plenzat 8.

content: Fawn, in spite of his fine horns, runs from the dog.

Wienert FFC LVI 63 (ET 257), 89 (ST 12): Halm Aesop No.
303.

child: Thieving nature of the fox will show itself.
Prostitute will deceive new lover as always.
Washerman as minister thinks of washing and fails the king.

content: Eagle killed with arrow made with his own feather.

Wienert FFC LVI *64 (ET 277), 117 (ST 273); Halm Aesop No.
4; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Monk under pressure from abbot forgives the crucifix which
has fallen and hurt him.

He says that
nevertheless there will always be hatred between them. *Wesselski Arlotto II
222 No. 90; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 336.

An apparently happy man lets another see the actual misery
of his existence. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 223.
child:
Apparently happy woman discloses the skeleton of her slain
paramour.
Habitual food and drink continued even when it is harmful.

Conservative but absurd way of slaughtering hog stubbornly
kept.

content:
Cat ceases catching rats as soon as he is given a home in a
monastery.

Thus with lazy priests. Pauli
(ed. Bolte) No. 573.

Collier and fuller cannot live together: one makes things
clean, the other soils them.

Wienert FFC
LVI 85 (ET 513), 121 (ST 305); Halm Aesop No. 59.
Man rejects bride because she seems immature.

Her father reassures him that she has had several children
already. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
No place secret enough for sin.

Alphabet No. 3; Wienert FFC LVI 80 (ET 458), 138 (ST 441);
Halm No. 354.
Hog goes to bath but wallows in the mud.

Time seems short to those who play, long for those who
wait.

So says servant girl whose mistress
upbraids her for late hours. Wesselski Bebel I 185 No. 39.
King grows lean from fear of death.
Dog allowed to warm self in house begins to bark.
Is chased off. Chauvin III 39 No. 1.
Many books do not make a scholar.
child:
Many books do not make a scholar: youth tricks mother by
carrying many books.

content:
Wolf loses interest in the sermon when he sees a flock of
sheep.

A dervish preaches to him. Chauvin
II 125 No. 123; Scala Celi 50b No. 285; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
child:
Heron (crane) loses interest in heaven if there are no
snails.

content: Dividing after God‘s fashion: little to poor, much to rich.

*Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 233 No. 509, Bebel I 232
No. 149, Mensa Philosophica No. 63.

Priest has no friends until he becomes bishop: then they
flock to him.

Wealth is relative: beggar with horse, wife, or dog
considered rich by poorer beggar.
child: Grass serves as pleasant couch for poor.
Bid raised for queen’s favors until she hesitates.

Jester replies, “If a man have goods enough, he might have
a sovereign lady.” England, U.S.: *Baughman.

content:
Jester takes cow and tells king people have plenty of milk,
for “he who is warm thinks everyone else is.”
Optimist becomes pessimist when his money is stolen.
King in exile neglected, but courted when he regains throne.

child:
Dove‘s pride in her large brood linked with fear for their
loss.

Wienert FFC LVI 44 (ET 21), 141 (ST
470); Halm Aesop No. 358.

content: Price of object depends on where it is on sale.

Swallow killed in court house by snake laments injustice in
house of justice.
Justice depends on the point of view.
child: Hen complains that man eats her, but she eats ant.
A gift of property silences criticism.

A priest who has preached against lucrative places given
the clergy is silent when he receives one. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 546.

Man complains of injustice of gods‘ wrecking ship because
of one man’s sin.

He then kills whole
swarm of ants because one has stung him. Wienert FFC LVI 77 (ET 429), 103 (ST
161); Halm No. 118; Irish: O‘Suilleabhain 11, Beal XXI 305.

Wolf objects to lion stealing sheep from him although he
has himself stolen it.
Judge reduces penalty when accused is his own son.

content: Praise what your master likes and scorn what he dislikes.
Ruler forces bishop to ordain ignorant priest.

Largest burdens laid on smallest asses: best offices to
most ignorant men.

Man so constantly enriched by God that he cannot give all
his goods to the poor.
Small trespasses punished; large crimes condoned.
child:
Ass punished for stealing mouthful of grass; lion and wolf
forgiven for eating sheep.

Animals confess sins to one another: fox and wolf forgive
each other; punish ass.
Animals confess sins to lion holding court.

All the powerful animals forgiven. Ass and lamb are
punished. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Penitent in confession worries about little sins and
belittles the big ones.

*Wesselski Arlotto
I 191 No. 17; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

He who steals much called king; he who steals little called
robber.

*Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 351; Scala
Celi 20a No. 120; Alphabet No. 334; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Wolf punished for theft; kings honored.

content: Ruler exiles subject for trivial remark.
Fool laughs at the absurdities he sees about him.

(1) Sees a man who is to
die that day buy shoes. (2) Sees sheriff leading a man to the gallows: a big
thief leading a little one. (3) Sees farmer weeping at funeral of his child,
while priest (the real father) sings. Wesselski Mönchslatein 193 No. 153.
child:
Dwarf king (fairy) laughs at the absurdities he sees about
him.

(1)
Sees man who is to die that day complain that his shoes are too thin. (Cf.
†J2174.) (2) Sees women adorn their heads when they are immoral below. (Cf.
†J2050.) (3) Sees man remove from his wife’s garment dust gathered
while she lay with another man. (Cf. †J2301.3.) (4) Sees persons making plans
while forgetting to say, “If God wills.” Irish
myth: *Cross.
Philosopher laughs at the vanities and sins of the world.

content: Unworthy rewarded instead of the worthy.

Cock killed by his captors in spite of his plea of
usefulness to man.

Smallness of offense no excuse when hunter prepares to kill
lark.

She has stolen but a single grain of
wheat. Wienert FFC LVI 64 (ET 273), 146 (ST 513); Halm Aesop No. 209.
Wolf unjustly accuses lamb and eats him.

When all the lamb’s defenses are good the wolf asserts the right of the strong over
the weak. (Usually accused of stirring up water from lower in stream.) (Cf.
†U141.) Wienert FFC LVI 50 (ET 97), 148 (ST 526); Halm Aesop No. 274; *Crane
Vitry 191 No. 135; Herbert III 12; Alphabet No. 631; Jacobs Aesop 199 No. 2;
Italian Novella: Rotunda; Indonesia: DeVries‘s
list No. 83 (monkey and goat).
child: Cat unjustly accuses cock and eats him.

Although all the cock’s defenses are good the cat tells
him that she can no longer go hungry and eats him. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Crow exercises rights of strong over dove who cannot defend
self.

Dove at crow‘s request sings to save
her brood which crow kills after song. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

content:
Wolf as commander orders all booty divided, but keeps his
own.

Wienert FFC LVI 47 (ET 58), 103 (ST
157); Halm Aesop No. 281.
Lion cub killed by bull gives lioness no right to complain.

Wienert FFC LVI 50 (ET 92), 129 (ST 367); Halm Aesop No.
395.
Rich man (king) seizes poor widow’s (nun‘s) cow.

Herbert III 40ff. No. 39; Hervieux IV No. 40; Irish myth:
*Cross.
child: Nobles ruin peasant’s (widow‘s) crops with impunity.

content: Nobleman murders one of the people.
child:
Nobleman who kills one of the people is brought to justice
only after long delay.

content:
The fathers have eaten sour grapes and the children‘s teeth
are set on edge.
